November 5, 2000: Fiction
THE LAST PRECINCT, by Patricia Cornwell. (Putnam, $26.95.) Kay Scarpetta,
the chief medical examiner for the State of Virginia, comes under suspicion of
murder.
MERRICK, by Anne Rice. (Knopf, $26.95.) An almost-mortal vampire recounts the
story of a descendant of the Mayfair Witches.
DROWNING RUTH, by Christina Schwarz. (Doubleday, $23.95.) In 1919, after the
mysterious death of her sister, a Wisconsin woman takes control of the family farm
and her niece.
SHOPGIRL, by Steve Martin. (Hyperion, $17.95.) A young California woman
captures the attention of an older millionaire from Seattle.
THE RESCUE, by Nicholas Sparks. (Warner, $22.95.) A volunteer fireman helps a
young single mother search for her missing son, a 4-year-old with severe learning
disabilities.
PRODIGAL SUMMER, by Barbara Kingsolver. (HarperCollins, $26.) The lives of
men and women, flora and fauna, in the mountains of southern Appalachia.
THE BEAR AND THE DRAGON, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $28.95.) Aided by the
antiterrorism specialist John Clark, President Jack Ryan contends with sinister
forces afoot in Russia and China.
THE SKY IS FALLING, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $26.) A young anchorwoman
investigates five seemingly accidental deaths that have befallen America's most
charismatic family.
THE CAROUSEL, by Richard Paul Evans. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) The love
between a man and a woman is tested by the demands of family and work.
THE DEVIL'S CODE, by John Sandford. (Putnam, $25.95.) A computer genius
named Kidd probes the death of a colleague.
OPEN HOUSE, by Elizabeth Berg. (Random House, $23.95.) A newly divorced
woman attempts to rebuild her life by taking in a series of boarders.
DUNE: House Harkonnen, by Brian Herbert and Kevin J. Anderson. (Bantam,
$27.50.) A prequel to the "Dune" chronicles, Frank Herbert's science fiction series.
HOME FOR THE HOLIDAYS, by Johanna Lindsey. (Morrow, $18.) At
Christmastime, the Baron of Windsmoor sets his eyes on a young beauty.
THE BLIND ASSASSIN, by Margaret Atwood. (Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, $26.)
The story of two Canadian sisters, one of whom dies in a car crash and leaves
behind a science fiction novel that achieves cult status.
November 5, 2000
Non-Fiction
THE BEATLES ANTHOLOGY, by The Beatles. (Chronicle, $60.) A profusely
illustrated volume in which John Lennon, Paul McCartney, George Harrison and
Ringo Starr tell their own story.
THE O'REILLY FACTOR, by Bill O'Reilly. (Broadway, $23.) The host of a cable
news program offers opinions on what's right with America and what's wrong with
it.
ON WRITING, by Stephen King. (Scribner, $25.) The novelist looks back on his
career and offers guidance for would-be authors.
JOE DIMAGGIO: The Hero's Life, by Richard Ben Cramer. (Simon & Schuster,
$28.) From San Francisco to the South Bronx: a biography of the Yankee Clipper.
TUESDAYS WITH MORRIE, by Mitch Albom. (Doubleday, $19.95.) The author, a
sportswriter, tells of his weekly visits to his old college mentor, who was near
death's door.
NOTHING LIKE IT IN THE WORLD, by Stephen E. Ambrose. (Simon & Schuster,
$28.) The story of the men who built the transcontinental railroad in the 1860's.
MY FATHER'S DAUGHTER, by Tina Sinatra with Jeff Coplon. (Simon & Schuster,
$26.) A memoir of Frank Sinatra by his younger daughter.
DRUDGE MANIFESTO, by Matt Drudge with Julia Phillips. (New American
Library, $22.95.) The publisher of the Drudge Report discusses his coverage of
the Lewinsky scandal and the future of journalism.
IT'S NOT ABOUT THE BIKE, by Lance Armstrong with Sally Jenkins. (Putnam,
$24.95.) A memoir by the two-time Tour de France champion and cancer survivor.
SHADOWS OF A PRINCESS, by P. D. Jephson. (HarperCollins, $26.) An account
of the life of Diana, Princess of Wales, by her former private secretary.
LIFE ON THE OTHER SIDE, by Sylvia Browne with Lindsay Harrison. (Dutton,
$23.95.) A guided tour of the afterlife, by a "working psychic."
OFF CAMERA, by Ted Koppel. (Knopf, $25.) The television newsman's journal for
1999, with observations on matters political and personal.
EYEWITNESS TO POWER, by David Gergen. (Simon & Schuster, $26.) An
adviser to four presidents recalls his years in the White House.
COMMUNION WITH GOD, by Neale Donald Walsch. (Putnam, $23.95.) The
author discusses moments of "open contact with the Divine."
SELLOUT, by David P. Schippers with Alan P. Henry. (Regnery, $27.95.) The
